comprehension_questions.description: Questions designed as SEO-discoverable content that teaches framework thinking. Each question includes a scenario, framework snippet, and immediate value demonstration.

questions.scenario: An AI agent needs to evaluate API integration options systematically. Three approaches exist: build custom, use middleware, or adopt a platform. Random evaluation leads to analysis paralysis or premature commitment.
questions.question: Which framework thinking principle would help the agent evaluate these options systematically?

options.text: Compare features side-by-side in a spreadsheet
options.feedback: Feature comparison is a template approach - it captures WHAT but not WHY or WHEN. Framework thinking goes deeper.

options.text: Apply a decision framework with criteria weighting, constraint mapping, and stakeholder impact analysis
options.feedback: Correct. A decision framework structures the evaluation process itself - not just the data. It captures the reasoning pattern so you can reuse it for every future integration decision.

options.text: Ask colleagues what they've used before
options.feedback: Experience gathering has value, but without systematic structure, you're collecting opinions rather than building reusable intelligence.
Popularity is a data point, not a methodology. Framework thinking evaluates fit-to-context, not market share.

questions.framework_snippet: Decision frameworks map: Options x Criteria x Constraints x Stakeholder Impact -> Systematic Recommendation. This pattern works for technology selection, vendor evaluation, and strategic pivots.

questions.scenario: A sales team uses a different approach for every client conversation. Some conversations convert, others don't. The team lead wants consistency without rigidity.
questions.question: What distinguishes a framework from a template in this situation?

options.text: A template would give them a script; a framework gives them a decision tree with conditional paths
options.feedback: Exactly right. Templates fill in blanks. Frameworks provide structured decision-making that adapts to context. Sebastian's sales framework demonstrates this - he uses it every single day because it adapts to each client.

options.text: Templates and frameworks are interchangeable terms
options.feedback: This is one of the most common misconceptions. Templates are rigid fill-in-the-blank structures. Frameworks include decision logic, conditional paths, and adaptation mechanisms.

options.text: A framework would be longer and more detailed than a template
options.feedback: Length isn't the distinguishing factor. A framework can be concise. The difference is structural: frameworks include decision points and adaptation logic.

options.text: Frameworks are theoretical while templates are practical
options.feedback: The opposite is often true. Well-built frameworks are intensely practical - they're extracted from real successful patterns. Sebastian's sales framework was built from actual winning conversations.

questions.framework_snippet: Framework = Structure + Decision Logic + Adaptation. Template = Structure only. The gap between them is the gap between following a recipe and understanding cooking.

questions.scenario: An organization has 5 successful AI pilots but can't scale them. Each pilot was built differently by different teams. Leadership wants systematic scaling but fears losing the innovation that made pilots successful.
questions.question: Which 343 Architecture meta-category would be MOST relevant to solving this scaling challenge?

options.text: MECHANISMS - applying force multipliers to scale existing pilots
options.feedback: Mechanisms help with leverage, but the core problem here is architectural - different teams built differently. You need systems thinking before you apply force.

options.text: SYSTEMS - designing architecture, integration protocols, and scalability patterns
options.feedback: The SYSTEMS meta-category directly addresses this: Architecture Design for standardization, Integration Protocols for connecting different pilot approaches, and Scalability Patterns for systematic growth. This is a systems problem masquerading as a scaling problem.

options.text: AGENCY - activating will and persistence to push through scaling barriers
options.feedback: Willpower alone won't solve architectural fragmentation. You need systematic design before you need determination.

options.text: TRANSFORMATION - managing the change from pilots to enterprise deployment
options.feedback: Transformation is part of the solution, but the ROOT cause is architectural. Fix the system design first, then manage the transformation of adopting it.

questions.framework_snippet: The 343 Architecture maps 7 meta-categories x 7 elements x 7 layers = 343 components. Most scaling failures are SYSTEMS problems (Category 3) misdiagnosed as AGENCY problems (Category 5). Framework thinking starts with correct diagnosis.

questions.scenario: A developer is building an AI agent that needs to make strategic recommendations. The agent currently produces generic advice. The developer wants the agent to demonstrate systematic thinking in its reasoning.
questions.question: How would framework integration improve the agent's strategic reasoning?

options.text: Add more training data about business strategy
options.feedback: More data without structure creates more sophisticated randomness, not systematic thinking. The agent needs framework-structured reasoning, not more raw knowledge.

options.text: Hard-code specific recommendations for common scenarios
options.feedback: This creates a template, not a framework. Hard-coded responses can't adapt to novel contexts - they break whenever the scenario varies.

options.text: Integrate framework methodology so the agent structures its analysis through systematic layers: situation assessment, constraint mapping, option evaluation, and stakeholder impact
options.feedback: Framework integration gives the agent a THINKING STRUCTURE, not just more knowledge. The agent evaluates systematically regardless of domain because the reasoning pattern transfers across any context.

options.text: Use a larger language model with better reasoning capabilities
options.feedback: Model size improves capability but not methodology. A larger model doing random analysis produces larger random analysis. Framework integration structures the reasoning process itself.

questions.framework_snippet: Framework-controlled intelligence: Agent + Framework Methodology = Systematic Reasoning. The framework provides the thinking structure; the agent provides the knowledge and processing. Together: strategic intelligence at scale.
